1892
The favored five on whose enwreathed brows
The laurel crowns of Poesie descend
To them alone Mnemosyne allows
Fame which with Time itself shall only end.

1882

Unites the sturdiness of England strong,
Will be no victim of the Conqueror Time,
He is a living part of English song.
The Art of Love; yea, and the Love of Art
Are the two notes with which Rossetti plays
Upon the chords of each admiring heart.
Throughout "the Golden Summer of his
days."

1889
The Poet, not of Fancy, but of Thought,
Of Thought both deep and lasting—this
was he
Who out of cold Philosophy well wrought
A living chain of verse which always we
Admire and love, because it has the storm
And tempest of the night, and all the day's
Brightness and calm—and with but little form
Of Poetry 'tis deserving of all praise.

The Muse of Poetry veils her shining face
And mourns alone, dispairing and apart.
Gone is the wealth, the beauty and the grace!
Gone is the Voice that sang to every heart!
Gone is the Singer, but the Song remains
And, since the Singer liveth in his Song,
The Laureate still is here and ever reigns
Enshrined in England's love through ages
long.

Morris, and clothed him with a mystic haze.

days

when stilled

N Saturday, January 19, 1907, Sargent's great picure "The Four
Doctors" was unveiled. To quote from a leader in the Baltimore
News, "The four men, who were the original members of the Faculty
of Medicine of Johns Hopkins University, and whose eminence, each
in his own field was the chief source of great distinction which that
part of the University attained almost immediately upon its foundation will be commemorated forever in a notable work of art."
Whether this picture is the greatest work of Sargent or no, it
is is enough to say that it is the work of the artist's mature years
when his discernment is at its best and his mastery of technique
facile. They are few who will not accord to the American cosmopolite, the title of the greatest living portrait painter.
Sargent has ever been noted among artists as one "who paints the thing as he sees it
for the God of things as they are." Women of fashion have winced under his treatment, and
so have men of distinction, but the man who is really great has nothing to fear in his hands,
for Sargent tells the truth.
It is singularly felicitous, then, that the University, whose motto
Veritas Vos Liberabit"
has been most scrupulously acted on, should have in its archives so accurate and so truthful
a record of its great men.
This picture may lead to the addition of others but should it not, the influence, be it
unconscious, will be great. The wonderful composition, the admirable brush work, the
accurate draughtsmanship, can not help but be an inspiration to all.

THE SOMBRE CARD.
I.
It is a country side of great holdings and
large houses. The hills are covered with forests of primeval timber. From little clefts in
the rock, little springs bubble and boil out,
thence fall in small cascades down into little
verdant valleys, and as the brooks grow they
join and flow into the great river of the Ohio.
Many of the houses are quite old and the
families have held them for somewhat over a
hundred years—a great space of time in the
West.
Since I was born I have spent much time
in one of these formless, massive, houses with
many wings, great chimneys and high walls
surrounding old fashioned gardens and moribund orchards.
In one of the long summer afternoons of
August when I was quite a child I accumulated my dearest possessions: a copy of the
Count of Monte Christo, a supply of cornsilk,
matches and cigarrette papers, and a stick
with a nail in the end sharpened for use in
spearing frogs.
I stole out through the garden all fragrant
with currant and gooseberry odors, fallen rose
leaves and pungent with poppies. Past the
sage, the feathered asparagus spotted with
red berries, a drink at the spring-house and
then I plunged into the willows, a cool retreat
from the glare of the sun.
For an hour I amused myself with the cornsilk cigarettes and the Count of Monte Christo
and then I began to wonder if somewhere on
the place there might not be a treasure cave,
underground passages or the like, at least a
ghost.
After reflecting, I remembered that the only
romantic thing in the neighborhood which
was available was the oecupant of the
"Sombre Gard."
About ten years before on a Good Friday a
young man had appeared in the quiet neighborhood. He had all the ear marks of a
gentleman. His clothes were black and carefully pressed, his hair was light, his eyes
were green and the long lashes gave him the
air of being able to look at the surrounding
world without in the least betraying what he
thought, and at the same time withdrawing

himself from view. He gave no cause for his
coming, answered all questions without any
information as to his past escaping his lips.
In his bearing he was intensely reserved—a
hauteur with the graces of a man of the world
joined to the qualities of an ascetic.
Then he bought a small place—a stone
house with a high stone wall about it and
there he stayed.
It is not possible in a small and inquisitive
community to shut yourself off from your
neighbors without the rise of stories and
rumors. It was said by some that the young
man was an exile from a foreign country, by
others that he was a fugitive from justice,
and since he did not go to communion it was
suggested that he was a Rosicrucian or a
member of some terrible and secret sect. But
for all that, the young man only appeared at
dusk walking along some lonely lane or riding
a great black stallion. He never inquired at
the postoffice, and few if any knew his name.
And so he lived his solitary life, and except
for a month every year in which it was
thought he went away, he stayed on bothering no one and requiring the same consideration from the men of the valley.
Now here was an adventure worthy of the
mood which was on me. An awe had filled
the countryside, and full grown men had been
heard to say that though they would give
much to know what was behind that stone
wall there was little on this earth that would
tempt thin to enter either by fair means or
foul. There were stories of wild bears who
guarded the "Sombre Gard," and of great
dogs and serpents, and for all I know of
winged dragons that protected the sanctity of
the place.
By following the little brook by whose purling waters I had been sitting I came at last to
the farm which belonged to the Man in Black.
In these ten years the place had grown up in
underbrush, in weeds, the fences were covered
with morning glories, poison ivy, and in many
cases there were no fences at all.
The little brook wound in and out among
the willows and sycamores until it reached a
stone wall, at which it flowed under. By getting down on my hands and knees and crawling down 11 tunnel I was able to get inside the
grounds. But at the end of the tunnel were

and above them was the miniature of a young
woman—not pretty but beautiful. The face
was willful and proud, and there were certain
lines in her face about the eyes that I did not
like, and yet the face was so beautiful that it
transfixed me.
The four other books were bound in yellow
and black with illustrations, which I have

"Papillon."
"Creme Yvette."
"L'Enfant Diable."

Above these was the pretty face of a woman
in the costume of a fancy dress ball, it seemed
to me. Her looks were alluringly seductive
and her lips full and smiling.
I did not pay the same attention to the rest
of the room. It looked like our library at
home except that the large table was covered
with papers and a typewriter stood with a
sheet of paper in it ready for use. Around
the walls were photographs of famous men
autographed, and some manuscript pages were
framed also.
I pushed on to the next room. There I
beheld an altar with burning candles. The
room was pitch black. The walls were hung
with velvet and above the altar was a painting of the Madona. I was awed.
In the next room, down a long passageway,
I found a room hung in green and yellow.
Divans were ranged around and in the centre
I saw a magnificent statue in white marble—
it was a Venus. I caught a heavy sickly odor
and then in a far corner of the room I beheld
a brazier on a tabourette, then I started.
Death pale, with a pipe long and queerly
shaped, I saw in a comatose condition the
man of the "Sombre Gard."
Not for nothing had I read the "Opium
Eater" and the "Count of Monte Christo."
I was scared, I turned and fled from that
terrible presence.
At dinner I would say nothing of where I
had been, but all noticed in my manner an
unusual silence. But I could not help thinking I was again to meet the man of the
"Sombre Gard."

THE "ATHLETIC CRAZE" AT OXFORD.
The Duke of Wellington is popularly supposed to have said that the battle of Waterloo
was won upon the playing fields of Eton. As
the battle of Waterloo was won by the Prussians, and the Prussian element is never very
conspicuous in the English public schools,
we must suppose the noble Duke failed, in
this instance, to combine epigrammatic force
and strict veracity. However this may be,
the advocates of excessive athletics have
always quoted the Duke of Wellington's remark, in order to prove that what they say
about the value of athletics is true.
No one doubts for a moment that athletics
are of the utmost importance in man's life.
The physical and moral training received from
them in boyhood have a far reaching effect on
the health and character of a man throughout
his life. But the object of these few remarks
is not to pour forth platitudes about games; it
is meant to show that games can be carried to
excess, and Oxford is the place where this is
most palpably obvious.
To understand properly the system of games
at an English University, one must first consider how they are regarded at the great
public schools. Most men who go to Oxford
have been at a public school from the age of
thirteen to that of eighteen, and it is there
that they gain all their athletic training.
These schools are all alike as regards
Cricket, which, being the English national
game, is universally played. But with other
games it is different.; some schools play
"Rugger," others play "Soccer;" some play
Hockey, others do not; those schools which
are near a river set great store by their rowing,
the others have to eschew aquatic pursuits
altogether; some schools, such as Eton,
Harrow and Winchester, play a kind of football peculiar to themselves, and are only just
beginning to take up "Rugger" and "Soccer."
The consequence is that, when these boys
go up to Oxford or Cambridge, they are encouraged to keep together in small bands or
cliques. Often a large number of boys from
the same school go up to the same college at
Oxford, and that college gains in reputation
for being a "Rugger" or a "Soccer" college,
according as the majority of its members is
drawn from a "Rugger" or a "Soccer"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

school. This is all very well in moderation,
but it means that Oxford is dominated by an
Athletic Spirit. Many a man would sooner
get a "Blue" (that is to say, would sooner represent Oxford against Cambridge in any of
the branches of athletics) than a First Class
in the schools. Many a man comes up to
Oxford merely in order to get a "Blue," and
consequently does only so much work as is
absolutely necessary for the passing of the
most elementary examinations.
These, moreover, are usually the men who
become leaders of the college, and from whom
the college takes its tone, which is only
natural, seeing that they have far more time
than any one else to go round and visit their
friends, and shine prominently in the social
world of the college.
This is unfortunate. Intellect, unless it be
backed up by muscle, has to surrender the
pre-eminence to brute force; conversation is
largely about athletics; and "training" and
kindred subjects become the lodestars which
guide the athletic aspirant's life. Cases,
though fortunately not many, are on record
of the authorities in a college offering scholarships to prominent public school athletes
who, without monetary assistance, would be
unable to come up to Oxford.
Athletics do then play a very large part in
the life of an Oxford undergraduate, and the
consequences of the tendency for interest in
them to increase are, as has been noted above,
that athletic tastes tend to bring men together
into small groups to the exclusion of those,
in the life of whom athletics play but a secondary part. Also college tone is liable to be
formed by the athletes of a college, who are
always a minority, and the tone thus formed
is not always as high as it might be.
The tendency then to athletics in excess is
dangerous, and it is one which should he
guarded against, not only at Oxford, but in
all such institutions. Sufficient time is given
to sports of all kinds, a sufficient interest is
taken in them in their legitimate spheres, to
make the undue emphasis that is laid upon
them, very unnecessary and in many ways
injurious. College games at Oxford take
place every afternoon, and are played with the
utmost keeness and energy. It is a great
feat to be in any of the college teams, and a

9

greater feat still to be chosen out of all the
3,000 undergraduates to play for Oxford
against Cambridge, and so win the coveted
dark blue scarf. But when the games are
over, and an hour has been spent in discussing
them and theorizing about the "might have
been," it is a pity to spend the rest of the
evening and most of the next day in a fruitless
effort to decide whether Jones was really offside or whether the referee was intoxicated.
The purpose of these remarks is not in the
least to decry Athletics; that would be folly,
but they are written in the hope that the
present state of things at Oxford—a state of
things against which there is sure shortly to
be a reaction—n-my be a warning to other institutions of a somewhat similar nature. The
good which Athletics do for a man is so great
that every one is tempted to err on the side of
excess rather than of deficiency in respect to
the time given to them, but the evils of a
deficiency in this are obvious to all, whereas
few, unless it has been forcibly brought home
to them, take the trouble to consider the evils
of excess. He is a wise man who remembers
that "there is a time for all things."

Once more the NEWS-LETTER arises to utter
a cry against what it deems an evil at the
University, and that is the condition of the
lights in the cage. All this year, that is,
since October, the lights have given a great
deal of trouble, and we think that some of
this trouble has been unnecessary. Some
nights, there would be as many as half of the
lamps out of commission. When such was
the case, any lacrosse practice was absolutely
out of the question. Almost every day an
electrician can be seen, working on the lamps
at the top of a ladder, but, even with this
constant repair, there is seldom a night when
all the lights are on duty. Now, why not
install, say, two of those brilliant lights, such
as ornament the front of the Gayety Theatre?
Doubtless, many of our readers are familiar
with the excellence of those lights. Two or
three lamps like them would make the cage
almost as bright as day, might save the lighting bill, and would help the athletic teams immensely.

THE SOMBRE CARD.
I.
It is a country side of great holdings and
large houses. The hills are covered with forests of primeval timber. From little clefts in
the rock, little springs bubble and boil out,
thence fall in small cascades down into little
verdant valleys, and as the brooks grow they
join and flow into the great river of the Ohio.
Many of the houses are quite old and the
families have held them for somewhat over a
hundred years—a great space of time in the
West.
Since I was born I have spent much time
in one of these formless, massive, houses with
many wings, great chimneys and high walls
surrounding old fashioned gardens and moribund orchards.
In one of the long summer afternoons of
August when I was quite a child I accumulated my dearest possessions: a copy of the
Count of Monte Christo, a supply of cornsilk,
matches and cigarrette papers, and a stick
with a nail in the end sharpened for use in
spearing frogs.
I stole out through the garden all fragrant
with currant and gooseberry odors, fallen rose
leaves and pungent with poppies. Past the
sage, the feathered asparagus spotted with
red berries, a drink at the spring-house and
then I plunged into the willows, a cool retreat
from the glare of the sun.
For an hour I amused myself with the cornsilk cigarettes and the Count of Monte Christo
and then I began to wonder if somewhere on
the place there might not be a treasure cave,
underground passages or the like, at least a
ghost.
After reflecting, I remembered that the only
romantic thing in the neighborhood which
was available was the oecupant of the
"Sombre Gard."
About ten years before on a Good Friday a
young man had appeared in the quiet neighborhood. He had all the ear marks of a
gentleman. His clothes were black and carefully pressed, his hair was light, his eyes
were green and the long lashes gave him the
air of being able to look at the surrounding
world without in the least betraying what he
thought, and at the same time withdrawing

himself from view. He gave no cause for his
coming, answered all questions without any
information as to his past escaping his lips.
In his bearing he was intensely reserved—a
hauteur with the graces of a man of the world
joined to the qualities of an ascetic.
Then he bought a small place—a stone
house with a high stone wall about it and
there he stayed.
It is not possible in a small and inquisitive
community to shut yourself off from your
neighbors without the rise of stories and
rumors. It was said by some that the young
man was an exile from a foreign country, by
others that he was a fugitive from justice,
and since he did not go to communion it was
suggested that he was a Rosicrucian or a
member of some terrible and secret sect. But
for all that, the young man only appeared at
dusk walking along some lonely lane or riding
a great black stallion. He never inquired at
the postoffice, and few if any knew his name.
And so he lived his solitary life, and except
for a month every year in which it was
thought he went away, he stayed on bothering no one and requiring the same consideration from the men of the valley.
Now here was an adventure worthy of the
mood which was on me. An awe had filled
the countryside, and full grown men had been
heard to say that though they would give
much to know what was behind that stone
wall there was little on this earth that would
tempt thin to enter either by fair means or
foul. There were stories of wild bears who
guarded the "Sombre Gard," and of great
dogs and serpents, and for all I know of
winged dragons that protected the sanctity of
the place.
By following the little brook by whose purling waters I had been sitting I came at last to
the farm which belonged to the Man in Black.
In these ten years the place had grown up in
underbrush, in weeds, the fences were covered
with morning glories, poison ivy, and in many
cases there were no fences at all.
The little brook wound in and out among
the willows and sycamores until it reached a
stone wall, at which it flowed under. By getting down on my hands and knees and crawling down 11 tunnel I was able to get inside the
grounds. But at the end of the tunnel were

I caught a glimpse of the massive iron gateway with a much bolted and chained wicket
beside it. In fact the residence of the Man

fortress and more awful than a grave yard.
None the less the door was standing open

wall clock and the pounding of a hammer in

The place was apparently deserted. Taking

Above these was the pretty face of a woman

I did not pay the same attention to the rest
of the room. It looked like our library at
home except that the large table was covered
with papers and a typewriter stood with a
sheet of paper in it ready for use. Around
the walls were photographs of famous men
autographed, and some manuscript pages were
framed also.
I pushed on to the next room. There I
beheld an altar with burning candles. The
room was pitch black. The walls were hung
with velvet and above the altar was a painting of the Madona. I was awed.
In the next room, down a long passageway,
I found a room hung in green and yellow.
Divans were ranged around and in the centre
I saw a magnificent statue in white marble—
it was a Venus. I caught a heavy sickly odor
and then in a far corner of the room I beheld
a brazier on a tabourette, then I started.
Death pale, with a pipe long and queerly
shaped, I saw in a comatose condition the
man of the "Sombre Gard."
Not for nothing had I read the "Opium
Eater" and the "Count of Monte Christo."
I was scared, I turned and fled from that
terrible presence.
At dinner I would say nothing of where I
had been, but all noticed in my manner an
unusual silence. But I could not help thinking I was again to meet the man of the
"Sombre Gard."

keenly, others of the despair I had and the
last of the life of dissipation which I led to
kill the pain. The life of a recluse gave me
ample time to polish and perfect the volumes.
At last I was sure of myself; I published them
anonymously. Ever before me came the
picture of the woman who had given me up,
because she thought me unstable and lazy,
and great was my joy when I learned that the
public had gone wild about the work. You
can not understand the pleasure I had in saying to myself, "If she only knew, but she
must not know." Then one month a year I
would come east and watch her as she knelt
in church, as she went to dances; I have even
dined with her in disguise. But she was not
happy, she is not happy now. I have gotten
over it I sometimes think. I have tasted the
greatest sorrow and the most intense satisfaction. I have lived in bustling crowds and in
solitude. I have plunged into the most
violent excesses and have lived the most
severe of lives. I can see through the lives
of people, I can sympathize with their faults
and shortcomings. But love is dead; I could
not love the woman any more. I love her
memory and she loves me."
"Two nights before you met me I was in the
theatre; the woman was there in a box also.
She spied me out in the audience and turned
white as a sheet. Shortly I was summoned
to her box. Last night I called on her. I
told her all. With tears in her eyes she
asked me for forgiveness. I forgave, for I
sympathized; but I told her I did not love
her. She had changed; she had no soul."
Here he stopped, and as I went out to bathe
I heard the door below shut.
The next day brought astonishing news. I
received the following note:
DEAR CARRUTHERS:
Although we have just met—as the world would
say, I can not help but realize that you know more
than any one of my life. I make you my literary
executer, and in my will I have bequeathed you the
property of the Sombre Gard. I shall have the
fullest confidence in you. I have left this world.
Yours,

JOHN ST. JOHN.
But I can not help thinking that Jack St.
John is still alive. Where I can not say. He
was one of those souls who was too far above
this world to live in any thing else but solitude.
He was a genius.

THE "ATHLETIC CRAZE" AT OXFORD.
The Duke of Wellington is popularly supposed to have said that the battle of Waterloo
was won upon the playing fields of Eton. As
the battle of Waterloo was won by the Prussians, and the Prussian element is never very
conspicuous in the English public schools,
we must suppose the noble Duke failed, in
this instance, to combine epigrammatic force
and strict veracity. However this may be,
the advocates of excessive athletics have
always quoted the Duke of Wellington's remark, in order to prove that what they say
about the value of athletics is true.
No one doubts for a moment that athletics
are of the utmost importance in man's life.
The physical and moral training received from
them in boyhood have a far reaching effect on
the health and character of a man throughout
his life. But the object of these few remarks
is not to pour forth platitudes about games; it
is meant to show that games can be carried to
excess, and Oxford is the place where this is
most palpably obvious.
To understand properly the system of games
at an English University, one must first consider how they are regarded at the great
public schools. Most men who go to Oxford
have been at a public school from the age of
thirteen to that of eighteen, and it is there
that they gain all their athletic training.
These schools are all alike as regards
Cricket, which, being the English national
game, is universally played. But with other
games it is different.; some schools play
"Rugger," others play "Soccer;" some play
Hockey, others do not; those schools which
are near a river set great store by their rowing,
the others have to eschew aquatic pursuits
altogether; some schools, such as Eton,
Harrow and Winchester, play a kind of football peculiar to themselves, and are only just
beginning to take up "Rugger" and "Soccer."
The consequence is that, when these boys
go up to Oxford or Cambridge, they are encouraged to keep together in small bands or
cliques. Often a large number of boys from
the same school go up to the same college at
Oxford, and that college gains in reputation
for being a "Rugger" or a "Soccer" college,
according as the majority of its members is
drawn from a "Rugger" or a "Soccer"

school. This is all very well in moderation,
but it means that Oxford is dominated by an
Athletic Spirit. Many a man would sooner
get a "Blue" (that is to say, would sooner represent Oxford against Cambridge in any of
the branches of athletics) than a First Class
in the schools. Many a man comes up to
Oxford merely in order to get a "Blue," and
consequently does only so much work as is
absolutely necessary for the passing of the
most elementary examinations.
These, moreover, are usually the men who
become leaders of the college, and from whom
the college takes its tone, which is only
natural, seeing that they have far more time
than any one else to go round and visit their
friends, and shine prominently in the social
world of the college.
This is unfortunate. Intellect, unless it be
backed up by muscle, has to surrender the
pre-eminence to brute force; conversation is
largely about athletics; and "training" and
kindred subjects become the lodestars which
guide the athletic aspirant's life. Cases,
though fortunately not many, are on record
of the authorities in a college offering scholarships to prominent public school athletes
who, without monetary assistance, would be
unable to come up to Oxford.
Athletics do then play a very large part in
the life of an Oxford undergraduate, and the
consequences of the tendency for interest in
them to increase are, as has been noted above,
that athletic tastes tend to bring men together
into small groups to the exclusion of those,
in the life of whom athletics play but a secondary part. Also college tone is liable to be
formed by the athletes of a college, who are
always a minority, and the tone thus formed
is not always as high as it might be.
The tendency then to athletics in excess is
dangerous, and it is one which should he
guarded against, not only at Oxford, but in
all such institutions. Sufficient time is given
to sports of all kinds, a sufficient interest is
taken in them in their legitimate spheres, to
make the undue emphasis that is laid upon
them, very unnecessary and in many ways
injurious. College games at Oxford take
place every afternoon, and are played with the
utmost keeness and energy. It is a great
feat to be in any of the college teams, and a

9

greater feat still to be chosen out of all the
3,000 undergraduates to play for Oxford
against Cambridge, and so win the coveted
dark blue scarf. But when the games are
over, and an hour has been spent in discussing
them and theorizing about the "might have
been," it is a pity to spend the rest of the
evening and most of the next day in a fruitless
effort to decide whether Jones was really offside or whether the referee was intoxicated.
The purpose of these remarks is not in the
least to decry Athletics; that would be folly,
but they are written in the hope that the
present state of things at Oxford—a state of
things against which there is sure shortly to
be a reaction—n-my be a warning to other institutions of a somewhat similar nature. The
good which Athletics do for a man is so great
that every one is tempted to err on the side of
excess rather than of deficiency in respect to
the time given to them, but the evils of a
deficiency in this are obvious to all, whereas
few, unless it has been forcibly brought home
to them, take the trouble to consider the evils
of excess. He is a wise man who remembers
that "there is a time for all things."

Once more the NEWS-LETTER arises to utter
a cry against what it deems an evil at the
University, and that is the condition of the
lights in the cage. All this year, that is,
since October, the lights have given a great
deal of trouble, and we think that some of
this trouble has been unnecessary. Some
nights, there would be as many as half of the
lamps out of commission. When such was
the case, any lacrosse practice was absolutely
out of the question. Almost every day an
electrician can be seen, working on the lamps
at the top of a ladder, but, even with this
constant repair, there is seldom a night when
all the lights are on duty. Now, why not
install, say, two of those brilliant lights, such
as ornament the front of the Gayety Theatre?
Doubtless, many of our readers are familiar
with the excellence of those lights. Two or
three lamps like them would make the cage
almost as bright as day, might save the lighting bill, and would help the athletic teams immensely.
The track system has begun, and judging
from the start the coming season should be a
banner one. The first meet of the season was
held at the Armory, January 5th, and the few
men entered from Hopkins managed to win
several places; Hunter 2nd in the 100-yard
dash, Stewart 2nd in the hurdles and Breyer
2nd in the mile.
